column2: P5JS - "Painting" on the canvas
What you'll do
Learn some key differences between the setup() and draw() functions that allow you to "paint"! (Part 3)
Welcome back! I'm excited to show you what I figured out - this is gonna be fun!
First things first - let's get back to that code editor. If you closed it after last time, go to https://editor.p5js.org and log in to get it back.
You should have a circle on the screen that moves around to follow your mouse. If not, you can go back to the last quest to get caught up.
Now it's time to take a closer look at the two main functions in this program: `setup()` and `draw()`
The `setup()` function happens once, at the very beginning. Currently, it just sets up the canvas and tells it what size to be.
The `draw()` function happens over and over again, as long as the program is running. Every few milliseconds, it runs the `draw()` code again.
That's why it looks like the circle is moving with our mouse. The program redraws it at our current mouseX and mouseY every few milliseconds!
It also redraws the background each time, covering up the last circle we drew.
But what would happen if we didn't redraw the background each time? What if we only drew it once, at the very beginning?
Let's find out! If we move the `background()` line of code to the `setup()` function, it will only happen once, right after the canvas is created.
Try it - move the `background();` line to right after the `createCanvas();` line. Make sure you put it before the `}` so it's in the right function.
Now run the program - what happens?
Woah! Is that what you thought would happen? If you want to start over, you can just hit the play button again.
So... did you notice how there's always a circle at the top left corner when you start? Why do you think that is?
Let's think about it - where is your mouse when the program starts? What values are mouseX and mouseY probably set to?
Exactly - your mouse is outside the canvas, so it draws the circle as close as it can.
Try weaving your mouse in and out of the canvas - you can decorate all the corners without touching the middle!
Can you figure out how to draw a happy face?
If you still have an outline around your circle, try using `strokeWeight(0)` to get rid of it and have a true paintbrush.
Woohoo! What else can you paint? To take a screenshot of your creation, press the 'print screen' key on your keyboard - the image will show up in your *Pictures* folder.
I'lll see you next time - we're going to keep digging deeper into *p5.js* and see what we can find!
